description: From Middle English progresse, from Old French progres (“a going forward”), from Latin prōgressus (“an advance”), from the participle stem of prōgredī (“to go forward, advance, develop”), from pro- (“forth, before”) +‎ gradi (“to walk, go”). Displaced native Old English forþgang.

entries.meaning: Movement or advancement through a series of events, or points in time; development through time. [from 15th c.]
examples: Testing for the new antidote is currently in progress.

entries.meaning: Specifically, advancement to a higher or more developed state; development, growth. [from 15th c.]
examples: Science has made extraordinary progress in the last fifty years.

entries.meaning: An official journey made by a monarch or other high personage; a state journey, a circuit. [from 15th c.]
examples: With the king about to go on progress, the trials and executions were deliberately timed.

entries.meaning: (now rare) A journey forward; travel. [from 15th c.]
Movement onwards or forwards or towards a specific objective or direction; advance. [from 16th c.]
examples: The thick branches overhanging the path made progress difficult.

description: From the noun. Lapsed into disuse in the 17th century, except in the US. Considered an Americanism on reintroduction to use in the UK.

verbs.description: progress (third-person singular simple present progresses, present participle progressing, simple past and past participle progressed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move, go, or proceed forward; to advance.
examples: Visitors progress through the museum at their own pace.

entries.meaning: (by extension) To improve; to become better or more complete.

examples: Or […] they came to progress matters in which Dudley had taken a hand, and left defrauded or bound over to the king.
